Description: Nissan, its former CEO and a former director agreed to pay $15 million to resolve allegations related to false financial disclosures that omitted more than $140 million to be paid to the CEO in retirement.

Info Source: Extracted from a spreadsheet obtained from the NLRB through a Freedom of Information Act request fulfilled on 5/28/2020.

Description: To resolve litigation alleged it discriminated against minority customers, Nissan Motor Acceptance agreed to change its practices and contribute $1 million to consumer education programs.
Private Litigation Case Title: Cason v. Nissan Motor Acceptance Corp.

Description: The Bureau found that Nissan and its agents: wrongfully repossessed vehicles; kept personal property in consumers' repossessed vehicles until consumers paid a storage fee; deprived consumers paying by phone of the ability to select payment options with significantly lower fees; and, in its loan extension agreements, made a deceptive statement that appeared to limit consumers' bankruptcy protections.

The Air Resources Board fined Nissan Motor Company $4.4 million for failing to meet requirements concerning the diagnostic equipment that monitors tailpipe emissions on most of its 2005-2007 models -- more than 450,000 vehicles.

Info Source: Contained in data received from the agency on January 25, 2021 in response to an open records request. The data was a spreadsheet compilation of information in the search engine at http://tdec.tn.gov:8080/pls/enf_reports/f?p=9001:710::::::

Description: Nissan agreed to a settlement worth an estimated $6 million to resolve class action litigation concerning serious engine defects.
Private Litigation Case Title: Duncan et al v. Nissan North America, Inc. et al

Description: Nissan agreed to pay over $97 million to settle its involvement in multi-district litigation connected to the use of dangerously defective Takata Corp. air bags.
Private Litigation Case Title: In Re: Takata Airbag Products Liability Litigation

Description: Nissan agreed to a settlement it estimated to be worth $10 million and the plaintiffs' lawyers estimated at $24 million to resolve class action litigation alleging that batteries in its electric vehicles lost capacity over time at an unreasonable rate.
Private Litigation Case Title: Humberto Daniel Klee et al v. Nissan North America Inc et al
